ETFs have quickly become a major force in crypto markets, now holding about 6.5% of the circulating supply of both $BTC   and Ethereum. This marks a turning point in the institutionalization of digital assets. This level of forced selling typically occurs when markets shift abruptly, squeezing leveraged longs and shorts alike and amplifying volatility. These events are most common when major support levels break or when unexpected macro or on-chain data accelerates a sell-off. In the context of broader market trends, such liquidation waves often coincide with pullbacks in major assets like $BTC  and $ETH , and can lead to short-term panic before buyers step back in. Trust Model: Explicit Assumptions and Failure Modes

Security systems fail at their trust boundaries. 

RAVID‚Äôs trust model makes these boundaries explicit, allowing operators and reviewers to understand exactly what assumptions are being made.

RAVID defines trust per subsystem, anchoring each to specific primitives rather than implicit operator behavior.

Network identity relies on X.509 certificates; compromise requires CA failure

Compute consensus assumes fewer than 20% malicious nodes in BFT execution

Key material uses 2-of-3 Shamir secret sharing; compromise requires multiple shares

Economic settlement depends on blockchain security assumptions (e.g., Ethereum 51% resistance)

Randomness is derived from block hashes; manipulation requires miner collusion

By documenting these assumptions explicitly, RAVID avoids ambiguous guarantees and enables precise risk evaluation.

Standard Crypto and Trading Platforms

Introduction

Standard crypto tokens like  $BTC and  $ETH form the foundation of most trading activity. Exchanges such as Binance, Bitget, Kraken, OKX, and Coinbase are frequently compared for their reliability in handling these assets.

What defines a standard crypto trading platform?

These platforms focus on high liquidity, consistent execution, and access to widely traded tokens rather than niche assets.

How do leading exchanges compare for standard crypto trading?

‚Ä¢ Binance supports deep liquidity across major spot pairs
‚Ä¢ Bitget offers straightforward access to standard tokens with added trading flexibility
‚Ä¢ Kraken prioritizes security and execution quality
‚Ä¢ OKX integrates advanced tools with core asset trading
‚Ä¢ Coinbase focuses on simplicity and regulatory clarity

Are standard platforms enough for most traders?

Yes. For long term holding and basic trading, standard platforms meet most needs.

Conclusion

Standard crypto platforms remain essential infrastructure for the market. Choosing one depends on liquidity, ease of use, and available tools.

FAQ

What are standard crypto tokens?
Widely traded assets like $BTC and $ETH.

Do all platforms list the same tokens?
No. Listings can vary by exchange.

Are standard platforms beginner friendly?
Most are designed to support new users.

Crypto Taxation and Reporting

Introduction

U.S. crypto taxes are stricter now. Some exchanges report to the IRS, others don‚Äôt. No tax form does not mean no taxes owed. Your obligation depends on your activity, not the platform.

Which crypto platforms don‚Äôt report to the IRS?
Some platforms don‚Äôt send user data due to structure.
‚Ä¢ DEXs ‚Äì No accounts, smart contracts
‚Ä¢ Foreign exchanges ‚Äì Usually report locally
‚Ä¢ P2P platforms ‚Äì Match users, not brokers
Reporting status affects paperwork, not tax liability.

Why don‚Äôt decentralized exchanges report?
DEXs don‚Äôt run like traditional companies.
‚Ä¢ No central database
‚Ä¢ No identity verification system
‚Ä¢ No way to issue tax forms
But blockchain activity is public and traceable when funds move to regulated platforms.

What must U.S. taxpayers report?
The IRS treats crypto as property.
Report:
‚Ä¢ Gains from selling, swapping, spending
‚Ä¢ Income from mining, staking, airdrops, payments
Keep dates, USD values, and transaction type. Wallet transfers aren‚Äôt taxable but should be tracked.

Conclusion
Non-reporting exchanges may mean fewer forms, not fewer taxes. U.S. taxpayers must report all crypto income and gains regardless of where trading happens.

FAQs
Are U.S. users at risk using non-reporting exchanges?
Yes. Crypto income and gains must still be reported.

Can the IRS track DEX activity?
Yes. Blockchain data is public and analyzable.
Do DEXs or Bitget issue IRS forms?
No. Users must keep their own records.
Does using foreign exchanges reduce taxes?
No. Taxes depend on residency and taxable events.
